data.title: BO 4.x connect to OpenLink "Virtuoso" db
data.meta_description:
Has anybody connected BO 4.x to OpenLink “Virtuoso”? 
It’s not clear to me from reading the OpenLink site if it’s just downloading a driver (ODBC?) and then adding approriate entries onto BO servers, similar to SQL serve…
data.text:
Has anybody connected BO 4.x to OpenLink “Virtuoso”?

It’s not clear to me from reading the OpenLink site if it’s just downloading a driver (ODBC?) and then adding approriate entries onto BO servers, similar to SQL server, or if it’s something different. The OpenLink site says you can use ODBC, JDBC, etc…but the step by step details of exactly how to make it work with BO aren’t clear to me. Appreciate feedback from anybody who’s actually done this, or tried and failed, pitfalls, etc.

Thanks

ccermak (BOB member since 2007-11-13)

[Moderator note - moved to the Semantic Layer forum]

Given what you have said, assuming you have details of the database why not try creating a connection and see if you can create a universe?

Nick Daniels (BOB member since 2002-08-15)

Couple different reasons.

First being I don’t have access to the db…yet, so it’s just theory at this point. It contains sensitive information and resides on it’s own dedicated domain, in CA and I’m in MN, with it’s own approvals etc. Security won’t let me connect to it and drag data across the WAN. Plan is to perform a POC by standing up a dedicated BO virtual server on the same domain as the db. This will take some time to get through the red tape…meanwhile I tried using the provided wizard on the OpenLink website to put in versions and OS’s to get to the correct driver, ODBC or otherwise, to download. No such luck, came up empty every time even selecting “Windows” on both fronts, meaning which OS is BO running on and which OS is “Virtuoso” running on, which seemed pretty vanilla.

ccermak (BOB member since 2007-11-13)

Questions about OpenLink Virtuoso are almost always best raised on the public OpenLink Discussion Forums, the Virtuoso Users mailing list, or through a confidential Support Case…

You can get the relevant Client Connectivity Kit for your needs from the main Virtuoso download page. For 32-bit client connections to Virtuoso 7, please use the Virtuoso 6 kit. 64-bit clients are better off with the Virtuoso 7 kit.

You can also set up a local Virtuoso instance for your own testing, while you await access to the corporate instance. For this purpose, you can use either the commercial version, under the two-week free trial license or any of the entry-level licenses available for purchase, or the Open Source version.

OpenLink (BOB member since 2013-12-05)

Thanks! That’s the type of response I was looking for

ccermak (BOB member since 2007-11-13)
